conclusion: Objects A and B start moving from the same location in the same direction.
The velocity-time graph for Object A shows a curve starting at \\( v_0 \\) and decreasing over time.
The velocity-time graph for Object B shows a straight line starting at \\( v_0 \\) and decreasing linearly over time.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, which can be determined from the slope of the velocity-time graph.
The slope of the graph at any point represents the acceleration at that point.
For Object A, the slope at \\( t_1 \\) is the tangent to the curve at that point.
For Object B, the slope is constant and can be calculated as the change in velocity divided by the change in time.

The slope of Object A at \\( t_1 \\) is not equal to the slope of Object B at \\( t_1 \\) because Object A's graph is a curve, and its slope changes over time, while Object B's graph is a straight line with a constant slope.
The two objects do not have the same acceleration at time \\( t_1 \\).
